channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Come be a Perl developer in the smartest city in the USA
item.description: We arenâ€™t a sexy Silicon Valley start-up with lots of venture capital backing us and swinging for the fences. Instead, weâ€™re an established business with a long-term reputation for being one of the best hosting companies in the world. We arenâ€™t sexy. Weâ€™re comfortable. And unlike most startups, we know weâ€™ll still be around tomorrow.

item.title: A role to give Perl Developers a warm glow... and powdered snow
item.description: If youâ€™re a firm believer in â€˜you only get what you giveâ€™, then this job should enable you to get an absolute shedload of stuff. Youâ€™ll be working for a company whose whole ethos is based around increasing fundraising for good causes, and youâ€™ll be directly helping them achieve this with the work you do on their platform.

item.title: Use Open Source Tools for a Righteous Cause (Artist Protection)
item.description: The music industry has changed drastically in the last twenty years. Free music reigns. That means, artistsâ€”at least those outside the mainstreamâ€“must work harder than ever to protect their lawful property. Copyright protection? Giggle, giggle. Itâ€™s simply not a priority for the biggest platforms (hello YouTube!).

item.title: Largest Perl team in London with beautiful Docklands offices
item.description: Large, dynamic Perl team in Canary Wharf looking for mid-level and senior developers. Run by a Perl-loving CTO in beautiful offices with a great view over Canary Wharf, the company manages one legacy Perl codebase and a whole bunch of very new, very shiny, and very modern codebases that power the market-leading solution in their particular area.

item.title: DNA and Dancer Down Under â€“ mid-level developer required for a bioinformatics company in Canberra
item.description: Scientists are still unravelling the many mysteries encoded within the DNA of organisms, and our client is working at the cutting edge in this field. Their software provides genotyping information about crops and can assist in the development of new species.

item.description: August 16-17, 2019 FlÃ¶rli Olten, Switzerland

item.description: August 7-9, 2019 Riga, Latvia

item.description: June 19-22, 2019 Strasbourg, France

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Azure Automation with Perl6 and Sparrow6
item.description: Alexey shows you how to automate interaction with Azure KeyVault. This case is typical as it often happens when one need to read secrets from keyvault and use them somehow.

item.title: German Perl Workshop (GPW) 2019 videos online
item.description: Daniel shares the videos of recently held very popular German Perl Workshop 2019. If you missed the event then this is your opportunity to watch the video. Special thanks to Lee Johnson and Julien Fiegehenn for all the hard work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 10: Roman Numerals and the Jaro-Winkler Distance
item.description: As always, Laurent, shared plenty of variations in his approach. It is always fun reading his blog. He always presents his solutions in both Perl5 and Perl6.

item.title: Converting Decimal to Roman Numbers in Perl 6
item.description: Joelle makes the challenge looks so easy with her style of writing. It is so easy to follow and understand.

item.title: Obiective Romanos grammaticam â€“ Perl weekly challenge, week 10
item.description: He is one of the few Perl6 experts in the team. He solved the challenge with the help of Grammar (Perl6). Please take a look if you want to learn more about Grammar in Perl6.

item.title: Roman Numerals in Perl 6
item.description: He is one of new member of the team and came up with a very well defined blog explaining his solution to Roman numerals challenge in Perl 6.

item.title: Roman Numerals with Perl 6
item.description: Arne Sommer, being on vacation last week, still managed to solve one of the challenge. If you look at the quality of his technical writing, it is priceless. A very good reference point for anyone learning Perl 6, very well explained in details.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 010
item.description: I love the way Adam Russell approached each challenge. It made me re-wired my own solution.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 010
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 011
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: A simple CLI app runner with commands in another namespace
item.description: Joel showing how he used Moo to not have to implement `new` and eschewed the base class.

item.title: Unusual HTML tags worth knowing
item.description: Christopher talks about some lesser known tags for you to have as many tools as possible on a daily basis.

item.title: Monthly Report - May
item.description: It is time for monthly report again. Plenty of activities to talk about.

item.title: Dispatch Tables and doing a LOT of work to stay DRY
item.description: Dave talks about Dispatch table follows DRY priniciple.

item.title: 25 years of Perl 5 releases
item.description: Tom shares the history of Perl5. A collection of interesting facts.

item.title: References, Dereferences and Perl
item.description: Dave revisits the basics of Perl in really interesting way.

item.title: Yancy's Static Backend
item.description: Doug Bell shares the ideas behind static backend for Yancy.

item.title: Get the most affordable premium labels for your business at StickerYou.com
item.description: Are you tired of spending your hard-earned dollars on labels that look cheap? Imagine if you could get far superior labels at a much lower cost. Well at StickerYou.com, you can! Order high-quality labels for your business, your family, your staff. StickerYou.comâ€™s online editor allows you to customize them in an endless number of shapes and sizes in minutes. Best of all there are no minimum order quantities! Better yet, use code PERL10 at checkout for 10% off.

item.title: #410 - Are you a blogger?
item.description:
Hi there

A few months ago, Gabor Szabo, raised a concern that not many people blog about Perl and its smart features. I have noticed that there is an improvement in the recent weeks. The Perl Weekly Challenge always encouraged its member to blog about their solutions. It is not just limited to Perl Weekly Challenge, I have also noticed Olaf Olders blogged about his experience of creating Twitter list of CPAN Authors. Similary, Damian Conway, blogged Why I love Perl6. And how can I miss, this blog, Alan Kay and OO Programming, by Curtis "Ovid" Poe, which started big dicussion on OO. I am sure there are plenty out there that I am not aware of. Please do share your blog with us if you have written one.

I found Twitter very helpful in spreading the word, I came across many such blogs (mentioned above) through my Twitter handle. I suggest we should have dedicated Twitter handle for all such technical blogs. In my humble opinion, you get to learn a lot about the subject by reading technical blog than any books. In technical blog, the author has the liberty to go into finer details and not worry about the size of the content.

Enjoy the ongoing Cricket World Cup and this week newsletter.
